newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: KL overnight rate rises on short-end squeeze.
newsitem.headline: KL overnight rate rises on short-end squeeze.

text.p: A shortage of funds at the short-end of the market boosted the overnight rate, dealers said.
The overnight rate ended at 7.50/8.0 percent from 7.00/30 previously, trading in a range of between 6.80 and 9.0 percent.
Dealers said the mismatch of funds caused the overnight's rise, with foreign banks holdings a lot of funds while local ones were short.
"The people who are long are the foreigners. They lend to Bank Negara before we can get at the funds at a higher rate," said a Malaysian bank dealer.
Other dealers said the squeeze was caused by banks shuffling assets to meet their requirements for the new month of June, including fulfilling statutory reserve requirements.
"A lot of guys were short. There's a lot of transfers to the new period," said a dealer at a mid-sized bank.
Earlier, other interbank rates headed higher mainly on borrowings by small finance houses and merchant banks.
The one-, two- and three-week money were at 7.50/70 percent against 7.40/50 previously, dealers said.
The one-month rate was at 7.50/60 percent versus 7.50, with the smaller houses having to pay up to 7.70 percent.
Three-month money was at 7.50/60 percent, unchanged, and the 12-month at 7.60/80 from 7.50/80.
Malaysia's release of first quarter economic growth of 8.2 percent was ignored as it was largely within market expectations, dealers and economists said.
Bank Negara said the manufacturing sector expanded 12.9 percent, up from 12.5 in the last quarter and lower than 13.9 percent in the year-ago quarter.
"GDP was slightly higher than what I projected. Manufacturing is the driver for the first quarter," said Zulkifli Hamzah, economist at Capitalcorp Securities.
